{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3662962,"name":"Trent Hekman","username":"Trent3669","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ecd19e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:22:35.067Z","cooked":"

Over the past few weeks, my robotics team has burned up many swerve motors. We are wondering what control methods, current limits, etc. other teams are using. We want to know if anyone has managed to burn up Kraken X60s through software means. We were using a supply current limit of 20A and the default stator current limit for all motors. The drive motors are being controlled using torqueCurrentVelocityFOC control mode, and the steering motors are being controlled with dutyCyleOut mode with a PID running on the RIO.

I am quite certain that this is not caused by debris entering the motors or other electrical issues, because the electrical system appears fine, and we did not do anything to expose the internals of the motors to metal shavings, especially not all 9 motors that we have burned up so far.

If anyone has any experience with this, we would greatly appreciate some advice. We would also like to know what motor control modes most teams are using for their swerve so we can replicate other teams control methods as closely as possible.

Thanks,
Trent from FRC team 3669

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T20:22:35.067Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":78,"reads":811,"readers_count":810,"score":627.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Trent Hekman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57231,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CarbonKnights"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/1","custom_user_title":"CarbonKnights","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3662983,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:32:34.022Z","cooked":"

Burning to the point of failing?

The Krakens (both X60 and X44s) have built in thermal protection that will limit motor power when you reach a certain temperature. We have overheated both types of motors to the limit with no permanent damage to the motors. I didn’t think it was possible to actually damage the motors by overheating them even with no current limits set.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T20:32:34.022Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":772,"readers_count":771,"score":189.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/2","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3662984,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:32:36.725Z","cooked":"

Wow!

So, any chance you can pull current logs (stator and supply)?
20A supply current seems almost too safe; 40A should be OK on the drives.
The default stator current is really high.

Are your tires wearing really fast too? Having the wheels fighting each other will result in lots of power consumption.

Oscillation (both in steering and drive) can also give you more power consumption than you should have, with lots of heating from braking after an over-shoot.

Are you killing both drives and steers, or just one type?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T20:32:36.725Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":747,"readers_count":746,"score":239.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/3","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663016,"name":"Trent Hekman","username":"Trent3669","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ecd19e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:41:26.581Z","cooked":"

I believe it has only been drive motors that have failed catastrophically (releasing magic smoke). We’ve had a few steering motor failures though. I don’t feel comfortable pulling the logs, for any of the motors that were getting hot, because we know that the electronics are already failing or have already caught fire.

Can you post your code repository?
From there, someone smarter than I am will be able to advise you on adding logging on the Rio, if not already implemented. The motor controllers do not keep their own logs as far as I know.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T20:45:46.856Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":664,"readers_count":663,"score":147.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663040,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:47:51.769Z","cooked":"

I’d be really surprised if the actual electronics in the Kraken were crispy… Motor windings are generally where the magic smoke comes from. That said, NEOs and SparkMAXs had a failure mode where the temperature sensor shorted to a winding and fried important things in the SparkMAX. BUT, that didn’t smell like anything

Any logs you can pull will really help with sorting out what’s going on! Current by motor from your power panel and battery voltage are kind of a minimum for diagnosis. The motor driver tracks a LOT more than that; winding temperature and stator current would tell us a lot. One question is: do you -log- it somewhere?

Dumb question: the wheels and steering turned freely by hand when the robot was off, right? If the mechanicals were fried enough to fail this test, you’d likely notice it… BUT, that IS something that could cause a LOT of power delivery when the electronics try to do what’s commanded.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T20:48:23.387Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":645,"readers_count":644,"score":134.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663054,"name":"Andrew McBride","username":"AndrewMcb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:52:48.879Z","cooked":"

Since it has not been stated already, Cross the road will definitely want to hear about this failure in more detail. CTRE and WCP work very hard to ensure there are no catastrophic failure modes on their motors, so hearing about one will prompt them to investigate with you more deeply. To the point potentially of having you send them a failed motor so they can root cause analysis the failure mode.

They are very responsive over email and phone in my experience, Contact Us – CTR Electronics

Sleep.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663057,"name":"Trent Hekman","username":"Trent3669","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ecd19e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T20:54:31.287Z","cooked":"

Yes, burning up to the point of failure. Basically, the circuitry just starts spontaneously melting down and won’t stop until we power down the robot. It’s almost like there’s an aluminum shaving causing a short inside the motor, but we don’t even build our robots out of aluminum. We build our robots out of carbon fiber. It could be carbon fiber working its way into the tiny cracks around the motor end cap, but we don’t think so though. Fibers that small you would not expect to be able to cause a short.

Just to clarify, same slot on the PDH? Have you tripped any breakers? Have you tried different breakers?

Trent3669:

especially not all 9 motors that we have burned up so far.

also, did you not consider taking a step back after motor number… 3 or 4? $1800 of motors is a lot to have possibly failing permanently, IMO, and after the first few, especially if its on the same mechanism, I’d take a step back and reconsider

We have not seen this issue with ours 8 in total. They are installed in the Mk4 SDS swerve modules with L3 ratios and have been used all season testing, 2 regionals, and champs.

As others have mentioned I too am interested in pictures, logs and the code being posted.

Here’s some pictures of one of the driver PCBs that burned up.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T21:36:48.271Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":522,"readers_count":521,"score":109.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Trent Hekman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57231,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CarbonKnights"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/17","custom_user_title":"CarbonKnights","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663228,"name":"Trent Hekman","username":"Trent3669","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ecd19e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T21:54:45.811Z","cooked":"

We have had motors in multiple different modules burn up. The breakers have never tripped. Power seems to be consistent to the motors. I will try logging some information from the currently operating motors to see if I can track down any issues related to supply power. We find it unlikely though. I’m starting to think that maybe carbon fiber strands are working their way inside the casing and causing the failure. I’ll ask CTRE if they think that it’s possible for a carbon fiber to cause this, because then we would need to find a better way to seal off the endcap.

Frankly, should you be running MORE motors before you contact and get a hypothesis from CTRE? Is it worth the possibility of burning up more 200$ motors?

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":55,"updated_at":"2025-06-24T23:15:38.531Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":492,"readers_count":491,"score":103.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503594,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-motors-burning-up","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57231,"username":"Trent3669","name":"Trent Hekman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ecd19e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-motors-burning-up/503594/19","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3663351,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T23:21:47.742Z","cooked":"

This exactly. The only time we’ve had serious repeated motor loss (with a Neo550, plus taking out a couple Sparks) was mid-competition, and forcibly getting back to the field is the only reason we didn’t shut down operation and sort out it. But we very quickly documented every operational detail with each break. When we did sit down and analyze, it was

  • Someone grabbed longer screws on accident, hitting the windings
  • The output ramping was off, and P gains very high, so we had high frequency, high torque thrashing of the systems.
  • Some motors were mounted incorrectly, causing cantilevering and non-axial strain.

This was a huge expensive mess that’s very similar to this case in concept. If you know something’s wrong, pump the brakes and at minimum start isolating variables in a least-likely-to-fail scenario. I’m all for scientific analysis, but when it’s this costly remove every potential system stressor at once and start building back up. Lower currents, drop your gains, double-check your wiring, everything.
